hyp_text: Greenland was discovered and settled by Norse Vikings around 982 AD, led by Erik the Red. In the Norse sagas, the explorer is said to have exiled himself in punishment for the killing of some of his fellow countrymen on a previous expedition to Iceland. The name means "green land" in Old Norse. The Vikings found the land uninhabited when they arrived. In the 13th century, Greenland's population reached between 3,000 and 5,000, arranged in a "Western Settlement", a "Middle Settlement", and, more sparsely populated, the "Eastern Settlement". They shared the island with the late Dorset culture people who occupied the northern and western coasts. The Norse settlements, such as Brattahlid, thrived for centuries but disappeared sometime in the 15th century, perhaps at the onset of the Little Ice Age. Beyond the specific settlements, the extent of Norse colonization was for a long time unknown, with written accounts suggesting exploration as far north as Hudson Bay marker . Recent archeological discoveries suggest that the area of Norse colonization included the Svalbard marker archipelago (71° N to 81° N), with a summer camp estimated to have been on the north coast of Isfjorden marker , Svalbard, on the boundary between tundra and polar desert. They may have explored north to Novaya Zemlya marker , as well. The Eastern Settlement was likely abandoned in the early to mid-15th century, during this period. In 1492, the pope confirmed the diocese of Gardar as being a Catholic bishopric. It is thus likely that by 1492 the Norse population in Greenland had become extinct. The last written record of the Norse Greenlanders records a marriage in 1408 in the Church of Hvalsey — today the best-preserved Nordic ruins in Greenland.
